narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Improved my vocabulary, learned words for how to speak more formally, and improved reading skills.

Xu Laoshi was fantastic, kind, and so generous with her time and energy. I learned a lot about modern china, chinese culture, and learned hundreds of words I would never have known. Learned how to communicate more fluently in formal chinese as well as casual, and figured out how to write about so many topics including politics (!), food, gender relations, tiger parents, and more. I loved this class (even though zoom is no fun!)
I learned grammar structures, new vocabulary, and gained a better understanding of Chinese culture.
better command of chinese language and culture
I learned more Chinese vocabulary, grammar, and culture.

In Chinese 152, I learned more about Chinese language and culture -- specifically, I learned about formal phrases in Chinese, and specific vocabulary relating to travel, food, politics, Chinatown, and more. Along with broadening my knowledge of Chinese characters, through the activities and homework in the class I was able to incorporate my new vocabulary into conversation and writing. I was also able to improve greatly in my speaking, listening, and reading. This course has made me more excited about learning Chinese and connecting back to my family's culture.
I learned how to speak fluent Chinese more formally, moving away from informal language. I also learned how to read and write more commonly used characters.

Learned a lot of Chinese; this ranged from things applicable in daily life (for example, talking about love) to more formal settings (talking about politics). This course material covered was actually developed in such a way to be useful, even to a relatively moderate/high level Chinese speaker. Typing and conversing in Chinese were also developed.

I learned more Chinese vocabulary and grammar, along with practicing my speaking/writing abilities. Moreover, we focused on topics like culture, upbringing, and family life that are specific to heritage learners.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Prof Xu made the class very engaging, and gave us opportunity to practice speaking. The vocabulary we learn is also useful in discussing events in daily life.

This class was fantastic. I think its hard to teach over zoom,but Xu Laoshi did a fantastic job keeping us engaged, being funny, sharing anecdotes, and being patient and understanding. The pace of learning can be really really rapid (we learned SO many words) but it ramps up in a reasonable way. Weaknesses- not much, I really think the class was good. Sometimes the weird canvas post hw was weird (the things where we had to critique a movie), just because there was no time to really read 100+ comments...

Xu laoshi was very good at maintaining a high level of energy even through Zoom, and she made sure everyone was involved in discussions in class. The class was very well organized and since it was taught over Zoom, the Chinese teachers adjusted the course content to make learning online more manageable while still teaching a significant amount of content. In terms of weaknesses, there were moments in class when we were covering grammar or vocabulary and it would be a bit dry. Also, the grades listed on Canvas often do not reflect your actual grade due to the way the professors calculate grades (a lot of the assignments we had to do were listed as 10 points out of 0 points total and skewed grades above 100), which can be a bit annoying.
I think the class time could be spent a little more productively

Strengths - very good teacher, quite interactive for an online course
Weaknesses - less opportunities to handwrite characters

Strengths:
I really liked the format of pre-learning phrases and other material before class began, and going reviewing important vocabulary during class instead of being taught less organically. I also enjoyed the small class size, because I was able to participate in class and interact more with the professor and my classmates. Additionally, I liked the group project at the end of class, and I felt that the daily quizzes were a good test of my understanding of the material. 

Weaknesses:
Since this was a language class, I think that the online format made it more difficult to have conversations and immerse ourselves in the discussion. However, in a normal year, this wouldn't be the case.
Professor Xu was a wonderful teacher that really made the class engaging and fun.

The course material was structured to be useful outside of the class setting; personally, this has been a strength of this course, since I have used the course material outside of class as well. Discussions are interesting, however virtual format makes discussions difficult to facilitate due to the virtual nature of the class. More clarity in coursework expectations would have been appreciated as well; for example, the instructors notified us that we could earn 'bonus' points for some assignments, which seemed to imply that these assignments were optional, when they in fact factored into participation grades. Better communication in the case of coursework in these cases could have been improved. Overall, instructors were very passionate and helpful in their teaching, and the course was fun and interesting in itself.
I thought the course was very strong and there's not much I would change.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Since the course content was adjusted this past semester (we only had three essays and the units were spread out across more days compared to a typical semester), the class felt very manageable, and I appreciated how the Chinese professors really took into account how much more difficult language learning over Zoom is. Since most of the classes were lecture-based and covered grammatical structures and vocabulary, it did feel a bit monotonous and boring at times.
The test format was verygood and the grading was fair, if not a bit too generous
Each class was heavily discussion based, and the teacher actively involved each of us in the lessons. If anything, I wish there were more opportunities to handwrite the characters.

Despite the limitations that COVID-19 has brought to a normal class, I really enjoyed CHNS 152 this year. Since it was a small class size, and because Xu Laoshi ensured that everyone could participate in class, it felt more normal and interactive, which I enjoyed.
Powerpoint presentations during the live seminars that everyone participated in worked.

Virtual discussions were suboptimal; discussions were difficult to hold in the virtual format, especially in large groups. The instructors did try their best with online activities such with Jamboards and Zoom breakout rooms, which were useful. More small discussion groups in breakout rooms would have been preferred, as these allowed for more discussion and were generally less awkward than large group discussions.
I liked that the teacher was very ready and able to meet with students. This was particularly helpful during the pandemic situation.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, even if you just need to fulfill a language requirement.
Yes! Xu LaoShi is an amazing professor and my Chinese improved a lot this semester. The way class is structured (homework, exams, projects) is very effective and helpful.
Yes! Xu Laoshi is fantastic. So kind, wonderful, sweet, and funny. I love her and will miss her!!

I would! As a heritage speaker, I was pleasantly surprised that there were so many grammatical nuances I was never aware of before this class. I also learned so much new vocabulary and feel like my Chinese has improved significantly over this past semester. The work was very manageable, and the professor was extremely kind and accessible. One important thing to keep in mind is that paying attention and taking notes during class lectures is essential- lots of the exam questions required you to understand small differences between two vocabulary words or when to use certain grammatical structures that were mentioned during class time.
Yes depending on chinese level
I would recommend this course to another student because the teacher is very nice and does a great job facilitating discussion to improve Chinese vocabulary and grammar.
I would definitely recommend taking this class! I am more excited to learn Chinese than before taking this course, and my knowledge of Chinese has definitely grown this semester.
Yes, this was a wonderful course that really allowed me to expand my Chinese skills, especially in formal use of grammar and vocabulary.

Yes - this course was very enjoyable and geared towards being useful even to Chinese speakers at different levels. This would be a good choice for fulfilling a language requirement, but also a very good choice for someone wanting to continue their Chinese education; the material and instructors made the course fun.
Yes, absolutely. Xu Laoshi is also incredible.
